lines.text:
[after waking his superior in the middle of the night]
Look, I know you don't like me. I don't blame you. But I had to talk to somebody, that's why I came here...
...sit down. What's wrong?
Thanks.

[seeing the grim look on Corday's face, and trying to break the tension]
What, did you kill somebody?

[laughs nervously]
No.
That's alright. I've heard about the girl. What's the trouble?
My father.
Oh, I see.
You see, if I get involved with her, I'm on my own. If I toe the line, I can have the residency at Chelsea. It's... well, you know what that means.
Yeah. I'd like to help you out... but nobody can make that decision - you have to make it for yourself.

[Dejectedly, as he gets up to leave]
You're right, I shouldn't have come here. I'm sorry. I'll just...

[takes out a bottle of whiskey]
. Sit down, sit down. I'm awake now. Let's have a drink together.

[smiles gently]
Okay.

You know, somehow you don't seem to qualify as a distress case. A ballplayer who's lost an arm, or a painter who goes blind. Let me tell you how I feel about it. Men like your father are tops. We had them in China. But the war kind of jumbles up things. You see a chest specialist doing eye surgery in an emergency station. An endocrine man, handling an amputation. That's when I discovered something. That whether you're doing a decompression on a man's head, or removing a splinter from his finger, you're part of the greatest fraternity in the world. There's nothing like it. Why, I'd be happy in your father's shoes, or as... as a country doctor. Just as long as I was on the team.

[after staring into his drink, he looks up]
That's what I wanted to hear. Something like that.
Now, don't get oversold. You see, what's right for me may be wrong for you. Ask yourself honestly, what it is that you want. And what you're willing to pay for it.

[smiles as he get he gets up to leave]
Thanks.

[smiles]
You know, every day I convert doctors to the practice of medicine.
You can't come back again.
I'm going to come back every day, twice a day. I'll give you two weeks to get strong - but you'll do everything I say and you'll eat everything I say. Then we'll be married and I'll move in here.
You'll never be happy! This is Third Avenue. You said we had nothing in common.
I was wrong.
And you'll never drill holes in anybody's head.
That's alright. I'll still be doctor - that's all that matters.
[Michael grabs Taffy, kisses her passionately and then they embrace]
Remember, it's only platonic... I looked it up.
